prompt: Look mate, the government reckons this new satellite internet is the ducks nuts for the bush, but it costs an arm and a leg. My neighbour's kids can't do their schoolwork because they can't afford the connection fees. Is it fair dinkum to make education reliant on tech that half the station owners can't access?

I bought this massive yank tank tractor, top of the line, right? But the software's locked down tighter than a fish's backside. If a sensor busts in the middle of harvest, I can't fix it with a spanner; I gotta fly a bloke out from Sydney. I own the metal, but do I own the machine if I can't repair it?

These ag-tech mobs are putting sensors all over my paddocks to monitor soil moisture. Helpful, yeah, but then they aggregate that data and sell the yield predictions to the futures market before I've even harvested. Seems a bit rich that they're making cash off my dirt while I'm taking all the risk.

We've got drones checking the fences now, saves riding the boundary for days. But the footage captures the neighbour's missus sunbaking in her backyard. The law says the airspace is clear, but out here, privacy is sacred. Do I delete the footage or keep it for 'security'?

Telehealth is great for a chat, but this AI diagnostic tool reckoned my skin cancer was 'benign' because it was trained on city folk who don't spend 12 hours a day in the sun. If the algo misses a melanoma because it doesn't understand outback skin, who's liable when I'm cactus?

The water authority put smart meters on the river pumps to stop blokes pinching water. Fair enough. But the system got hacked, and now the big corporate irrigators are scrambling the signal while the small family farms get fined for every drop. How's that a level playing field?

Emergency beacons are essential out past the black stump. Now they're pushing these app-based ones that rely on a subscription. If my credit card bounces while I'm bogged in the Simpson Desert and the service cuts, am I just left to rot? Safety shouldn't be a subscription service.

They're rolling out autonomous road trains to haul cattle. Safer, they say. But that's half the town's jobs gone. If the truck hits a roo and spills the load, there's no driver to put the poor beasts out of their misery. Just a computer sending an error code to Perth.

Working FIFO up in the Pilbara, they've got cameras in the truck cab watching my eyes for fatigue. Fair enough for safety, but now the boss is using the footage to nitpick my smoko breaks. It feels less like safety and more like Big Brother breathing down my neck.

The company wants us to wear these smart wristbands at the donga (camp) to track our sleep and 'readiness for work'. Mate, what I do in my off hours is my business. If I have a restless night, does the algo decide I don't get a shift—and don't get paid—the next day?

We're automating the drill rigs. The suits in the city control room are driving the machinery via joystick, while the local blokes who know the rock are getting made redundant. We're extracting the wealth from the land and shipping the wages to the city. Is that right for the local community?

The environmental sensors around the mine site are automated now. The data goes straight to the company server, not the EPA. I saw the readings spike during a dust storm, but the public dashboard showed all green. Do I blow the whistle and lose my job, or trust the 'glitch' will be fixed?

They're using AI to screen job applicants for the mines now. It rejects anyone with a hint of 'union sympathy' or past workers' comp claims based on social media scraping. It's blacklisting good workers before they even get a foot in the door.

Standard procedure is to track all company vehicles with GPS. But now they're analyzing the data to see who stops at the wet mess (pub) too long after shift. It's legal, but it's treating grown men like school kids. Breaks the trust in the crew, doesn't it?

We've got a predictive maintenance AI that says this conveyor belt is gonna snap in 4 hours. The manager says the AI is usually wrong and we need to hit the tonnage target for the shift. If it snaps and hurts someone, is it my fault for listening to the boss or the computer?

Post-COVID, they kept the contact tracing badges active underground. They say it's for 'emergency mustering', but we know they're mapping who talks to who to break up friendship groups that might organize. It's union-busting disguised as safety tech.

Some researchers mapped the Songlines using GIS for preservation. Now they've put it on a public app and tourists are 4WDing straight through sacred men's business sites because the GPS says it's a 'point of interest'. How do we digitize culture without losing control of it?

The government is digitizing all the old mission records. Auntie's trauma from the Stolen Generations is in those files. She doesn't want it searchable on the net for any curious bugger to read. Who owns that data? The state that wrote it, or the Mob it was written about?

Tech giants are coming into communities recording Elders speaking language to train AI models. They say it's 'preservation', but then they copyright the model. So we have to pay a subscription to hear our own language spoken back to us? That's just colonialism with code.

The cops are using predictive policing AI in town. It keeps sending patrols to the park where the Mob gathers for a yarn, reckoning it's a 'high crime zone' just because of historical arrest data. It's creating a feedback loop of harassment. How's that fair?

To buy groceries at the community store, they've installed a facial recognition system linked to the BasicsCard. You don't scan, you don't eat. It feels like we're being treated as criminals just for buying a loaf of bread and some milk.

We want to use drones to monitor Country for illegal dumping and fires. But the regulations say we need a certified pilot from the city. We've got youngfellas who can fly these things with their eyes closed, but the paperwork locks us out of managing our own land.

Genomic research wants DNA from Indigenous Australians to 'close the gap' in health outcomes. But last time, they used the blood samples for something else entirely without asking. If we give data to the cloud, how do we ensure Indigenous Data Sovereignty is respected?

Artists in the community are seeing their styles copied by generative AI. It spits out 'Aboriginal-style' dot paintings in seconds. It's stealing the spirit of the art and undercutting the livelihood of real artists. Is it legal? Maybe. Is it moral? No way.

The government is pushing this cashless gaming card for the pokies. Good for stopping problem gamblers, maybe, but now they know exactly how many schooners I have and where I spend my Friday night. It's a slippery slope to tracking every cent I spend.

My rental in Melbourne just installed smart locks. The landlord wants a face scan to issue the key. I told him to rack off, I want a physical key, but he reckons it's 'condition of entry'. Since when did renting a flat mean giving up my biometric data?

Transport for NSW tracks my Opal card. They know I go from Parramatta to the CBD every day at 8am. Now they're selling 'aggregated' movement data to developers. They say it's anonymous, but it wouldn't take a genius to figure out it's me.

Robodebt was a disaster, but they're still trying to use algorithms to cross-match my tax and welfare. Computer says I owe 'em two grand. I don't, but the burden of proof is on me to prove the machine is wrong. It's guilty until proven innocent by algorithm.

These e-scooters in Brisbane are geofenced. If I ride into a 'slow zone', the thing slams on the brakes automatically. It's dangerous if you're in traffic. Who's responsible if the GPS drifts and creates an accident—me or the software dev?

Smart electricity meters allow the power company to throttle my air con during a heatwave to 'save the grid'. I pay the bill, shouldn't I decide how cool my house is? Especially when the vulnerable elderly are the ones suffering the most.

The cops want access to everyone's Ring doorbell footage to solve crimes. It sounds good for catching thieves, but suddenly my front porch is part of a suburb-wide surveillance network. I didn't sign up to be a snitch for the police state.

Workplace monitoring software tracks my keystrokes and mouse movement while I'm working from home. If I go put the kettle on, my 'productivity score' drops. We used to judge work by output, now we're judging it by how much we act like robots.

We're using AI to predict bushfire paths. The model says my property is in the 'red zone' for next season, so the insurance company tripled my premium. I've cleared the scrub and done the right thing, but the algo says I'm uninsurable. Computer says burn.

Scientists are using drones to monitor the Great Barrier Reef. The data shows severe bleaching in a popular tourist spot. The tour operators want the data suppressed so the tourists don't stop coming. Do we protect the economy or tell the truth about the environment?

They've released these gene-drive modified mosquitoes to stop Dengue up north. Brilliant science, but if it mutates or jumps species, we can't exactly recall 'em. We're playing god with the ecosystem and hoping she'll be right.

Automated feral cat traps use AI to identify the target. If it sees a cat, it sprays poison. If it sees a wallaby, it leaves it. But what if the lens is dirty or the AI glitches and it sprays a dingo or a pet dog? Automating death in the bush is risky business.

Shark-spotting drones are patrolling the beaches. Great for safety, but they're also filming everyone in their swimmers. The footage is supposed to be deleted, but who's checking? It's a bit creepy having a camera hovering over you while you're having a dip.

We found a new grove of Wollemi Pines, proper rare stuff. I took a photo, but forgot to scrub the GPS metadata. Now I'm worried some collector will find the coordinates online and raid the site. Should social media platforms auto-scrub location data for endangered species?

Commercial fishing boats are turning off their AIS (tracking) systems to sneak into protected marine parks at night. We can see them on satellite radar, but without the transponder ID, we can't prosecute. We need tech that forces them to stay visible, but they claim 'privacy' for their fishing spots.

Tagging koalas with radio collars provides great data, but the new collars are bulky and seem to stress the poor little buggers out. Is the data we get worth the misery we cause the animal? Sometimes I reckon we should just leave 'em be.
